NEW PAGE 233
CHAPTER 4 USE STANDARDS
Section 4.4 Use-Specific Standards
d) A common building located within the common open space area may be included as an
accessory use, but in no instance shall the common building exceed 1,500 square feet or
serve as a permanent dwelling unit.
V. Lot Configuration
(AMENDED 6.21.22 UDOTA-3-22)
a) At least 60 percent of the individual building lots shall abut the common open space area,
not a street or alley.
b) Homes on street-facing lots shall include a front porch and shall not include an attached
garage that faces the street.
vi. Surface Parking
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
a) Pocket neighborhoods are exempt from the off-street parking standards in Table 5.1.D.9,
Table of Minimum Off-Street Parking Requirements, but shall include at least one parking
space for each dwelling unit plus one designated guest parking space for every four
dwelling units.
b) The pocket neighborhood may include a shared parking area that accommodates resident
and guest parking.
c) Provision of resident parking spaces within a shared parking area is not required in cases
where resident parking is provided through individual driveways or by parking spaces
along alleys.
d) In no instance shall parking areas be more than 300 linear feet from the dwelling it serves.
vii. Detached Shared Garages
If provided, detached garages serving more than one dwelling shall be accessed via a private
drive or alley. A garage shall not exceed five car bays or include individual garage doors wider
than 12 feet each.
viii.Storage Space
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
a) Each individual dwelling shall have at least 40 square feet of covered storage space
outside the heated floor area. Storage space may be located on an individual lot or on
common land adjacent to or within a common building.
b) Storage of up to two unlicensed (no license plate) or inoperable vehicles or trailers may
take place on a lot in the MDR and HDR districts, provided the vehicles or trailers are
located within an enclosed building or located behind the principal structure and outside
required setbacks.
ix. Perimeter Buffer
A pocket neighborhood shall incorporate a Type B perimeter buffer along all lot lines shared
with existing single-family detached dwellings.
X. Private Access
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
Vehicular entryways into pocket neighborhoods and accessways serving off-street parking
areas and individual dwelling lots shall be configured as private driveways.
C. Individual Lot Configuration
(AMENDED 6.21.22 UDOTA-3-22)
Table 4.4.A.14.c, Pocket Neighborhood Lots, sets out the dimensional requirements for individual
lots. In cases where these standards conflict with the applicable dimensional standards for the
zoning district where located, these standards shall control.
City of Burlington
Unified Development Ordinance
4-23
North Carolina
Last Updated 9.19.23

i.
Landscape/Use Easement
Any lot abutting another lot used for residential purposes in a pocket neighborhood shall be
subject to a landscape/use easement on one side that extends from the lot line to the exterior
wall of the dwelling (see Figure 4.4.A.14.c.i, Use Easement). The purpose for the use
easement is to ensure each dwelling can maintain a sense of privacy and useable outdoor
space within a pocket neighborhood where lots can be very small in size.

CHAPTER 4 USE STANDARDS
Section 4.4 Use-Specific Standards
b) At least two dwellings in a pocket neighborhood shall maintain a total square footage that
differs by at least 200 square feet in floor area from the average square footage of all
other dwellings. Nothing shall prohibit a configuration where all dwellings are different
sizes.
iii. Fences
Pocket neighborhoods are exempted from the standards in Section 5.3.H.2, Fences and Walls,
but shall comply with the following:
a) Fences within front yards or side yards forward of the front façade plane shall not exceed
three feet in height;
b) Fences in rear yards or side yards behind the front facade plane shall not exceed six feet
in height; and
c) In no instance shall a fence be placed within a use or access easement.
iv. Homeowner's Association
A pocket neighborhood shall include a homeowners' or property owners' association that
maintains control of common areas and takes responsibility for maintenance of common
features in the neighborhood established and configured in accordance with Section 6.9,
Owner Associations.
15. Single-Family Attached Dwellings
Single-family attached development shall comply with the following provisions:
a. Building Placement
i.
A minimum ten feet of separation shall be maintained between all buildings in the
development.
ii.
Buildings must be set back from private drives and parking lots a minimum of ten feet as
measured from back of curb or edge of pavement, if no curb is provided.
iii. Buildings shall be set back from public streets in the development in accordance with the
street setbacks for the district where located.
b. Maximum Number of Units per Building
Table 4.4.A.15.b, Maximum Number of Units in a Building, sets out the maximum number of
attached residential dwelling units allowed in a single building by zoning district:
C. Design
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
Single-family attached development may comply with applicable design standards in Section 5.5.D,
Multi-Family Residential Design Standards, with the consent of the landowner(s) at the time of
application to establish the development.
d. Recreation Facilities
Active recreation facilities must be placed a minimum of 50 feet from adjacent land used for single-
family detached residential purposes.
e. Utilities
All electric, communications, water and sewer utility lines shall be installed underground.

NEW PAGE 231
CHAPTER 4 USE STANDARDS
Section 4.4 Use-Specific Standards
C.
Design
Multi-family development shall comply with the applicable design standards in Section 5.5.D, Multi-
Family Residential Design Standards.
d. Recreation Facilities
(AMENDED 6.21.22 UDOTA-3-22)
Active recreation facilities must be placed a minimum of 50 feet from an adjacent single-family
detached residential dwelling.
e. Utilities
All electric, communications, water and sewer utility lines shall be installed underground.
f. Condominiums
Multi-family development configured as condominiums shall comply with the following standards:
i. Condominiums shall conform to the use and development requirements of this Ordinance for
the zoning district(s) where located.
ii.
Condominiums shall conform to the requirements of the North Carolina Condominium Act, in
Chapter 47C of the North Carolina General Statutes.
iii. Condominium ownership may be created by the owner or co-owners of a structure(s) by an
express declaration of their intention to submit such property to the provisions of the North
Carolina Condominium Act, which declaration shall be subject to approval by the City Council
and recorded in the office of the Register of Deeds in the county where the development is
located.
g. Screening
Utility areas such as clothes drying yards and outdoor storage areas shall be fully screened from
public streets and adjacent lots zoned for single-family detached residential dwellings.
14. Pocket Neighborhood
a. Purpose and Intent
A pocket neighborhood is a group of smaller single-family detached dwellings built in close
proximity to one another around a small green or commonly-owned open space with off-street
parking areas to the rear or in common areas. These use types are intended to provide greater
housing options as well as providing a means for accommodating infill in established portions of
the City (see Figure 4.4.A.14.a: Pocket Neighborhood Design).
City of Burlington

b. Site Configuration
i.
Development Size
A pocket neighborhood shall be located on a parcel of land at least one-third (1/3) of an acre
and no greater than four acres in area.
ii. Allowable Uses
a) Pocket neighborhoods shall be limited to single-family detached dwellings and accessory
uses.
b) Accessory uses may include common open space, a common building for the purposes of
storage or recreation, outdoor recreational features, and garages.
iii. Number of Dwellings
(AMENDED 6.21.22 UDOTA-3-22)
A pocket neighborhood shall include at least four dwellings but shall not exceed the maximum
allowable density of the underlying zoning district.
iv. Common Open Space
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20; 6.21.22 UDOTA-3-22)
a) A pocket neighborhood shall include common open space that comprises at least 40
percent of the total site and includes improved pedestrian walkways that provide
pedestrian access to each dwelling, shared parking areas (if provided), common buildings
(if provided), and connections to the public sidewalk network (if sidewalks are adjacent
to the development). The common open space shall include a central green, lawn, or
garden area fronting the dwellings and a perimeter buffer area that incorporates
landscaping materials, existing vegetation, or other features to buffer the pocket
neighborhood from adjacent development.
b) The central green or lawn area shall include at least 150 square feet of area for each
dwelling in the development.
c) The common open space in a pocket neighborhood is not required to provide active
recreation features, though such features may be provided.
City of Burlington

CHAPTER 4 USE STANDARDS
Section 4.4 Use-Specific Standards
f. Condominiums
Single-family attached development configured as condominiums shall comply with the following
standards:
i.
Condominiums shall conform to the use and development requirements of this Ordinance for
the zoning district(s) where located.
ii.
Condominiums shall conform to the requirements of the North Carolina Condominium Act, in
Chapter 47C of the North Carolina General Statutes.
iii. Condominium ownership may be created by the owner or co-owners of a structure(s) by an
express declaration of their intention to submit such property to the provisions of the North
Carolina Condominium Act, which declaration shall be subject to approval by the City Council
and recorded in the office of the Register of Deeds in the county where the development is
located.
g. Access
i.
Single-family attached developments shall abut a public street.
ii. Individual single-family attached lots need not abut a public street provided that every
dwelling unit shall be provided access to their property via either a public right-of-way or a
private vehicular or pedestrian way owned by the individual lot owner in fee or in common
ownership with other property owners in the development.
iii. Adequate access shall be provided for firefighting equipment, service deliveries, and refuse
collection.
h. Storage of Unlicensed or Inoperable Vehicles or Trailers
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
Storage of up to two unlicensed (no license plate) or inoperable vehicles or trailers may take place
on a lot in the MDR, HDR, or OI districts, provided the vehicles or trailers are located within an
enclosed building or located behind the principal structure and outside required setbacks.
16. Single-Family Detached Dwelling
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
a.
Modular homes shall comply with the standards in Section 160D-911 of the North Carolina General
Statutes and shall be treated as site-built single-family detached structures.
b.
Storage of up to two unlicensed (no license plate) or inoperable vehicles or trailers may take place
on a lot in the LDR, MDR, HDR, or OI districts, provided the vehicles or trailers are located within
an enclosed building or located behind the principal structure and outside required setbacks.
C. Single-family detached dwellings constructed in the CR district shall comply with the standards in
Section 5.5.E, Single-Family Residential Design Guidelines. Single-family detached development
in all other conventional districts may comply with Section 5.5.E, Single-Family Residential Design
Guidelines, with the consent of the landowner(s) at the time of application to establish the
development.
17. Tiny Home
(AMENDED 12.6.22 UDOTA-05-22)
a. Generally
A tiny home shall be permitted within the City's planning jurisdiction, subject to the standards in
this section.
b. Tiny Homes Distinguished
Tiny homes shall take one of the following three forms:
i. A manufactured tiny home, which shall be considered as a manufactured or mobile home
subject to the standards in this section;
ii. A movable tiny home, which shall be considered as a recreational vehicle or a travel trailer
subject to the standards in this section; or
iii. A site-built tiny home, which shall be considered as a single-family detached residential
dwelling subject to the standards in this section.
C. Standards Applied to All Tiny Homes
Regardless of the type of tiny home, any tiny home established after December 6, 2022, in the
City's planning jurisdiction shall comply with the standards applied to the particular type of tiny
home, as well as the following:

NEW PAGE 237
CHAPTER 4 USE STANDARDS
Section 4.4 Use-Specific Standards
i.
The maximum square footage for a tiny home shall not exceed 500 square feet;
ii.
In no instance shall a tiny home include more than two detached accessory structures;
iii. Tiny homes shall meet the off-street parking requirements in Section 5.1.D.2, Minimum Off-
Street Parking Spaces Required.
d. Manufactured Tiny Home Standards
i. A manufactured tiny home shall be configured in accordance with the standards established
by the North Carolina Department of Insurance and the most current version of the State of
North Carolina Regulations for Manufactured Homes.
ii.
An individual manufactured tiny home shall comply with the standards in Section 4.4.A.9,
Manufactured Dwelling, except that the following shall not be required:
a) A minimum width of 16 feet; and
b) A continuous masonry foundation or foundation curtain wall shall not be required.
iii. An individual manufactured tiny home may be located upon its own lot in accordance with
Section 4.2.C, Principal Use Table;
iv. In cases where two or more manufactured tiny homes are proposed on a single lot such
development shall comply with the standards in Section 4.4.A.10, Manufactured Dwelling Park,
except that such developments shall be permitted only within the RMH and CR zoning districts,
and that each manufactured tiny home shall require only one parking space.
e. Movable Tiny Home Standards
i.
A movable tiny home shall be configured in accordance with the applicable State and federal
standards established for recreational vehicles or travel trailers, as appropriate.
ii.
A movable tiny home may only be established in accordance with the standards in Section
4.4.C.38, Recreational Vehicle Park.
iii. In no instance shall a movable tiny home be used as a permanent residence.
f.
Site-Built Tiny Home Standards
A site-built tiny home may be developed in accordance with the applicable dimensional standards
for the zoning district where located, all standards applicable to a single-family detached
residential structures in this Ordinance, and all applicable State Building Code standards for
residential development including all applicable minimum room size and ceiling clearance
provisions.
18. Triplex/Quadriplex
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
Triplex and quadriplex dwellings shall comply with Section 5.5.D, Multi-Family Residential Design
Standards, and the following standards:
a. The dwelling shall face the street from which the dwelling derives its street address.
b. If a parking lot is provided, it shall be located to the interior side or rear of the dwelling and not
be located between the dwelling and the street.
C.
Storage of up to two unlicensed (no license plate) or inoperable vehicles or trailers may take place
on a lot in the MDR or HDR districts, provided the vehicles or trailers are located within an enclosed
building or located behind the principal structure and outside required setbacks.
19. Upper-Story Residential
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20; 3.4.21 UDOTA-01-21)
a. Generally
i.
Upper-story residential dwelling units shall occupy the second or higher floor of a building with
a non-residential use on the ground floor.
ii. Upper story residential units shall comply with the mixed-use design standards in Section
5.5.C, Mixed-Use Design Standards.
iii.
Upper-story residential units configured as condominiums shall comply with the standards in
Section 4.4.A.15.f, Condominiums.
b. Within the CBD District
Nothing shall limit the placement of residential floor area on the ground floor on lots within the
CBD district, provided the non-residential portion of the use has its own entrance or provided that
the building has a shared primary entrance. A non-residential portion of the building must occupy
the front façade of the street-level ground floor.

b) At least two dwellings in a pocket neighborhood shall maintain a total square footage that
differs by at least 200 square feet in floor area from the average square footage of all
other dwellings. Nothing shall prohibit a configuration where all dwellings are different
sizes.
iii. Fences
Pocket neighborhoods are exempted from the standards in Section 5.3.H.2, Fences and Walls,
but shall comply with the following:
a) Fences within front yards or side yards forward of the front façade plane shall not exceed
three feet in height;
b) Fences in rear yards or side yards behind the front facade plane shall not exceed six feet
in height; and
c) In no instance shall a fence be placed within a use or access easement.
iv. Homeowner's Association
A pocket neighborhood shall include a homeowners' or property owners' association that
maintains control of common areas and takes responsibility for maintenance of common
features in the neighborhood established and configured in accordance with Section 6.9,
Owner Associations.
15. Single-Family Attached Dwellings
Single-family attached development shall comply with the following provisions:
a. Building Placement
i.
A minimum ten feet of separation shall be maintained between all buildings in the
development.
ii.
Buildings must be set back from private drives and parking lots a minimum of ten feet as
measured from back of curb or edge of pavement, if no curb is provided.
iii. Buildings shall be set back from public streets in the development in accordance with the
street setbacks for the district where located.
b. Maximum Number of Units per Building
Table 4.4.A.15.b, Maximum Number of Units in a Building, sets out the maximum number of
attached residential dwelling units allowed in a single building by zoning district:
C. Design
(AMENDED 10.20.20 UDOTA-03-20)
Single-family attached development may comply with applicable design standards in Section 5.5.D,
Multi-Family Residential Design Standards, with the consent of the landowner(s) at the time of
application to establish the development.
d. Recreation Facilities
Active recreation facilities must be placed a minimum of 50 feet from adjacent land used for single-
family detached residential purposes.
e. Utilities
All electric, communications, water and sewer utility lines shall be installed underground.
